articles.headline: Bahrain Will Normalize Relations With Israel, in Deal Brokered by Trump
articles.snippet: The island kingdom in the Persian Gulf becomes the second Arab nation in a month to more openly embrace Israel, dismissing Palestinian objections.
articles.abstract: The island kingdom in the Persian Gulf becomes the second Arab nation in a month to more openly embrace Israel, dismissing Palestinian objections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced on Friday that Bahrain would establish full diplomatic relations with Israel, following the United Arab Emirates, in another sign of shifting Middle East dynamics that are bringing Arab nations closer to Israel.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Trump’s Payroll Tax ‘Cut’ Fizzles
articles.snippet: Big companies say the president’s directive to delay collection of the tax that funds Social Security is more trouble than it is worth. Federal employees are upset they are stuck with it.
articles.abstract: Big companies say the president’s directive to delay collection of the tax that funds Social Security is more trouble than it is worth. Federal employees are upset they are stuck with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With congressional negotiations stalled over a new round of pandemic aid, President Trump has floated the idea of once acting alone to stimulate the economy before the November election.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: How Colleges Became the New Covid Hot Spots
articles.snippet: Like meatpacking plants and nursing homes early in the pandemic, campuses across the country are experiencing outbreaks.
articles.abstract: Like meatpacking plants and nursing homes early in the pandemic, campuses across the country are experiencing outbreaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began last month with a trickle of coronavirus infections as college students arrived for the fall semester. Soon that trickle became a stream, with campuses reporting dozens, and sometimes hundreds, of new cases each day.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: The Woman Taking Over TikTok at the Toughest Time
articles.snippet: Vanessa Pappas is keeping a focus on the app’s community of creators and users as it deals with pressure from President Trump, Beijing and a possible sale.
articles.abstract: Vanessa Pappas is keeping a focus on the app’s community of creators and users as it deals with pressure from President Trump, Beijing and a possible sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago, as TikTok grappled with escalating tensions between the United States and China, the social media app’s top executives huddled together to figure out their next steps.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Taylor Lorenz

articles.headline: A Lifeline to the Jobless Has Problems With Fraud, and With Math
articles.snippet: An emergency federal program faces growing issues with spurious claims, and the flood of applicants may have led to overcounting the unemployed.
articles.abstract: An emergency federal program faces growing issues with spurious claims, and the flood of applicants may have led to overcounting the unemployed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, shortly after she advertised an apartment for rent in the Bay Area, Barbara Lamb found five envelopes from the state’s unemployment office in the building’s communal mail slot. They kept coming, day after day, until a stack of more than 30 piled up, bulging with notices of benefit approvals, questionnaires about job status — and debit cards with money.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Patricia Cohen, Conor Dougherty and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: A Line of Fire South of Portland and a Yearslong Recovery Ahead
articles.snippet: Firefighters continued to battle blazes along the West Coast that have now charred nearly five million acres. At least 17 people are dead, with dozens still missing.
articles.abstract: Firefighters continued to battle blazes along the West Coast that have now charred nearly five million acres. At least 17 people are dead, with dozens still missing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — A 36-mile-wide line of flames edged into the towns around Portland, Ore., and cities along the West Coast were smothered in acrid smoke and ash on Friday as history-making wildfires remained unchecked, killing at least 17 and leaving dozens of people missing.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Jack Nicas and Mike Baker

articles.headline: How China Brought Nearly 200 Million Students Back to School
articles.snippet: China says the reopening of classrooms proves that its top-down system is superior. To overwhelmed teachers and students stuck on campuses, its restrictions can feel like overkill.
articles.abstract: China says the reopening of classrooms proves that its top-down system is superior. To overwhelmed teachers and students stuck on campuses, its restrictions can feel like overkill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under bright blue skies, nearly 2,000 students gathered this month for the start of school at Hanyang No. 1 High School in Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus first emerged.
articles.byline: By Javier C. Hernández

articles.headline: Teen Stock Trading Seems Dangerous. It Doesn’t Have to Be.
articles.snippet: Gunslinging young investors are making stock ownership seem like a terrible idea for novices. But owning equities, with limits and guardrails, can teach kids plenty.
articles.abstract: Gunslinging young investors are making stock ownership seem like a terrible idea for novices. But owning equities, with limits and guardrails, can teach kids plenty.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year, Robinhood and its millions of younger-than-average customers have found themselves at the center of attention that is both comic and tragic.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Films Hit Festivals Trying to Create Buzz Without a Crowd
articles.snippet: The pandemic has upended the circuit, meaning smaller movies face an even greater challenge in attracting deep-pocketed distributors.
articles.abstract: The pandemic has upended the circuit, meaning smaller movies face an even greater challenge in attracting deep-pocketed distributors.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Some 70 cars crammed into a downtown Los Angeles parking lot surrounded by high rises and a smattering of food trucks on Thursday night to watch “Concrete Cowboy,” a father-son film starring Idris Elba and set in North Philadelphia’s Black cowboy community.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Trump Onslaught Against Biden Falls Short of a Breakthrough
articles.snippet: President Trump has leveled scathing law-and-order attacks on Joseph Biden for weeks. But a new poll shows Mr. Biden ahead in three states Mr. Trump hopes to pick up, and maintaining a lead in Wisconsin.
articles.abstract: President Trump has leveled scathing law-and-order attacks on Joseph Biden for weeks. But a new poll shows Mr. Biden ahead in three states Mr. Trump hopes to pick up, and maintaining a lead in Wisconsin.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Disney Wanted to Make a Splash in China With ‘Mulan.’ It Stumbled Instead.
articles.snippet: A political controversy over a filming location was a rare blunder for one of the world’s savviest companies in dealing with China.
articles.abstract: A political controversy over a filming location was a rare blunder for one of the world’s savviest companies in dealing with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Executives at Walt Disney Studios were celebrating. “Mulan,” a $200 million live-action spectacle five years in the making, had arrived on Disney’s streaming service to strong reviews, with critics lauding its ravishing scenery and thrilling battle sequences.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Amy Qin

articles.headline: As the West Coast Burns, Communities Unravel With Each Death
articles.snippet: The fires have killed at least 20 people, leaving families and communities devastated up and down the West Coast.
articles.abstract: The fires have killed at least 20 people, leaving families and communities devastated up and down the West Coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — They lived more than 500 miles from each other — one in the wooded foothills of the Sierra Nevada, northeast of California’s capital, Sacramento, the other in a thickly forested canyon east of Oregon’s capital, Salem.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio

articles.headline: Trump Pressed for Plasma Therapy. Officials Worry, Is an Unvetted Vaccine Next?
articles.snippet: New details of how the president has demanded faster action from health agencies help explain the intensifying concern that he could demand pre-Election Day approval of a vaccine.
articles.abstract: New details of how the president has demanded faster action from health agencies help explain the intensifying concern that he could demand pre-Election Day approval of a vaccine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was the third week of August, the Republican National Convention was days away, and President Trump was impatient.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: How Kamala Harris’s Immigrant Parents Found a Home, and Each Other, in a Black Study Group
articles.snippet: Donald Harris and Shyamala Gopalan grew up under British colonial rule on different sides of the planet. They were each drawn to Berkeley, and became part of an intellectual circle that shaped the rest of their lives.
articles.abstract: Donald Harris and Shyamala Gopalan grew up under British colonial rule on different sides of the planet. They were each drawn to Berkeley, and became part of an intellectual circle that shaped the rest of their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: At an off-campus space at the University of California at Berkeley in the fall of 1962, a tall, thin Jamaican Ph.D. student addressed a small crowd, drawing parallels between his native country and the United States.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: As Fires Disrupt Schools, ‘the Pandemic Has Actually Helped’
articles.snippet: After wildfires consumed an entire town, students and teachers who had planned for remote classes found some comfort in staying connected amid the chaos.
articles.abstract: After wildfires consumed an entire town, students and teachers who had planned for remote classes found some comfort in staying connected amid the chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ash fell from an apocalyptic orange sky as Jennifer Willin drove home last week from the only school in tiny Berry Creek, Calif., where she had picked up a pair of Wi-Fi hot spots for her daughters’ remote classes. Hours later, her cellphone erupted with an emergency alert: Evacuate immediately.
articles.byline: By Dan Levin and Kate Taylor

articles.headline: In Arab States’ Embrace, Israelis See a Reshaped Mideast
articles.snippet: Normalized ties with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain raise hopes in Israel that it is finally gaining acceptance in its volatile neighborhood.
articles.abstract: Normalized ties with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain raise hopes in Israel that it is finally gaining acceptance in its volatile neighborhood.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Since its founding, Israel has seen itself as a modern-day Sparta, a tiny fortress nation-state in a hostile desert, whose survival depended on its internal cohesion and sheer military strength.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: In Visiting a Charred California, Trump Confronts a Scientific Reality He Denies
articles.snippet: A president who has mocked climate change and pushed policies that accelerate it is set to be briefed on the scorched earth and ash-filled skies that experts say are the predictable result.
articles.abstract: A president who has mocked climate change and pushed policies that accelerate it is set to be briefed on the scorched earth and ash-filled skies that experts say are the predictable result.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump flies to California on Monday to assess the state’s raging forest fires, he will come face to face with the grim consequences of a reality he has stubbornly refused to accept: the devastating effects of a warming planet.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Oracle Chosen as TikTok’s Tech Partner, as Microsoft’s Bid Is Rejected
articles.snippet: The moves came as the clock ticks down on President Trump’s executive order to block the Chinese-owned social media app.
articles.abstract: The moves came as the clock ticks down on President Trump’s executive order to block the Chinese-owned social media app.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Chinese owner of TikTok has chosen Oracle to be the app’s technology partner for its U.S. operations and has rejected an acquisition offer from Microsoft, according to Microsoft officials and other people involved in the negotiations, as time runs out on an executive order from President Trump threatening to ban the popular app unless its American operations are sold.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, David McCabe and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: As Wildfires Burn Out of Control, the West Coast Faces the Unimaginable
articles.snippet: Firefighters across California and Oregon are bracing for stronger winds that could partly clear the air — but also fan the flames of uncontrolled blazes.
articles.abstract: Firefighters across California and Oregon are bracing for stronger winds that could partly clear the air — but also fan the flames of uncontrolled blazes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Across a hellish landscape of smoke and ash, authorities in Oregon, California and Washington State battled to contain mega-wildfires on Sunday as shifting winds threatened to accelerate blazes that have burned an unimaginable swath of land across the West.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Jack Healy

articles.headline: The Intercept Promised to Reveal Everything. Then Its Own Scandal Hit.
articles.snippet: Internal documents show how a source ended up in jail — and the fallout in the newsroom.
articles.abstract: Internal documents show how a source ended up in jail — and the fallout in the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where were you when you first heard about the Snowden leak?
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Japan’s Next Prime Minister Emerges From Behind the Curtain
articles.snippet: Yoshihide Suga’s years as a shadow power in Japanese politics left him a bit of a cipher.  Now he is emerging to take control of the world’s third-largest economy at a time of deep uncertainty.
articles.abstract: Yoshihide Suga’s years as a shadow power in Japanese politics left him a bit of a cipher.  Now he is emerging to take control of the world’s third-largest economy at a time of deep uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Yoshihide Suga charted an unlikely course to the cusp of Japan’s premiership.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Ben Dooley

articles.headline: For Prisoners in the West, the Virus and the Wildfires Are Colliding Threats
articles.snippet: Prisoners are more vulnerable than ever to the twin crises of the pandemic and a historic wildfire season.
articles.abstract: Prisoners are more vulnerable than ever to the twin crises of the pandemic and a historic wildfire season.
articles.lead_paragraph: As wildfires tore through huge swaths of Oregon this week, prisoners were hurried away from the encroaching flames — not to freedom but to an overcrowded state prison, where they slept shoulder-to-shoulder in cots, and in some cases on the floor. Food was in short supply, showers and toilets few, and fights broke out between rival gang members.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: A Tight Trump-Biden Race in Florida: Here’s the State of Play
articles.snippet: Elections in Florida are won by running up margins in favorable terrain while losing more closely in hostile precincts. Joseph Biden visits the state on Tuesday for the first time since claiming the nomination.
articles.abstract: Elections in Florida are won by running up margins in favorable terrain while losing more closely in hostile precincts. Joseph Biden visits the state on Tuesday for the first time since claiming the nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONGBOAT KEY, Fla. — As Linda Kanner hoisted groceries into her Volvo outside the Publix in this affluent Gulf Coast enclave last week, she unleashed a stream of invective toward President Trump to explain why she would “vote for Mickey Mouse” before an incumbent whose conduct she finds appalling.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: War Crime Risk Grows for U.S. Over Saudi Strikes in Yemen
articles.snippet: State Department officials have raised alarms about the legal risk in aiding airstrikes that kill civilians. The Trump administration recently suppressed findings as it sold more weapons to Gulf nations.
articles.abstract: State Department officials have raised alarms about the legal risk in aiding airstrikes that kill civilians. The Trump administration recently suppressed findings as it sold more weapons to Gulf nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The civilian death toll from Saudi Arabia’s disastrous air war over Yemen was steadily rising in 2016 when the State Department’s legal office in the Obama administration reached a startling conclusion: Top American officials could be charged with war crimes for approving bomb sales to the Saudis and their partners.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Edward Wong

articles.headline: TikTok Owner’s Big Reason to Strike a U.S. Deal: China Is Slowing
articles.snippet: ByteDance’s founder has long urged his employees to think beyond the world’s No. 2 economy, where growth is easing and competition is rising.
articles.abstract: ByteDance’s founder has long urged his employees to think beyond the world’s No. 2 economy, where growth is easing and competition is rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: TikTok’s Chinese owner has fought tooth and nail to keep control over its wildly popular platform for dancing teens and young Los Angeles influencers. One big reason: The days of fast internet fortunes and meteoric digital growth in its home market may be coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong
